Beautiful, sweet and hilarious

Some viewers have called Wish Dragon a rip-off of Aladdin because both stories feature a magical being who grants three wishes. But that comparison misses what makes Wish Dragon so special and unique.
First, the film is deeply rooted in Chinese culture and folklore, with its story set in modern-day Shanghai and featuring a wish dragon from a teapot rather than a genie from a lamp. The characters’ motivations and backgrounds are shaped by the realities of contemporary China, from family expectations to socioeconomic divides, making the story feel fresh and authentic.
While the wish-granting premise is familiar, Wish Dragon takes it in a new direction. The protagonist, Din, doesn’t just want wealth or romance—he’s driven by a genuine desire to reconnect with his childhood friend, Li Na. The film’s focus on friendship, sacrifice, and kindness gives it a different emotional core than Aladdin, which centers more on romance and personal gain. The dragon, Long, isn’t just a comedic sidekick; his journey is about learning the true meaning of life and friendship after centuries of selfishness.
The humor, vibrant animation, and action sequences are all top-notch, but what really makes Wish Dragon shine is its heart. The film explores what really matters in life—loyalty, compassion, and the bonds we share with others—in a way that feels genuine and moving. Even if the plot has some similarities to Aladdin, the execution, setting, and themes make it stand out as its own story.
In short, calling Wish Dragon a rip-off of Aladdin is an oversimplification. It’s a beautifully animated, funny, and touching film that uses a classic fairy-tale structure to tell a story that’s uniquely its own—and that’s why it’s so good.

Brilliantly written and completed with incredible performances from Jimmy Wong and Jon Cho, Wish Dragon is an impressive debut feature from up-and-coming animation juggernaut(and future John Lasseter) Chris Applehans.
